Israel only executed one man in its history since 1948--Adolph Eichmann--the genocidal maniac.  Not one terrorist mass murderer has been executed. In addition, you apparently have convicted the man of allegations that have not been proven in a court of law.

"Capital punishment is unjust."

Your assertion may be true. The debate concerning capital punishment, pro and con, will continue, with both camps making compelling arguments.

That said, we're talking about Egypt here, and about the Egyptian/Arab/Islamist mindset. Your position regarding capital punishment is irrelevant, in Egypt. And superimposing it upon the Arab mindset, is pointless, in my opinion.

As I'm sure that you're aware, Pew data shows that 80% of Egyptians favor stoning to death convicted adulterers, amputation of limbs for various crimes, severe punishment(s) for being homosexual and/or straying from Islam, genital mutilation of girls... just to name a few outlooks/practices that the Western mindset view as barbaric.

If Mubarak doesn't hang, it will most likely be due to it being somehow more advantagous to the powers-that-be to not hang him.

3 reasons why it would be bad to execute Mubarak:

1. At least officially, Mubarak resigned. Resignation is better than, say, staying in power indefinitely, as did Quadaffi. If both sorts of behavior merit the death penalty, then there's a moral hazard: why resign if there's no advantage to doing that than in fighting until the end?

2. Mubarak's behavior was not much worse than the behavior of the current military council--and who knows how bad the current situation will get? Ought the current regime's behavior merit executions as well? That would lead to a cycle of political violence, making reconciliation more difficult for Egypt.

3. Capital punishment is unjust. The idea that any iniquity deserves a pound of flesh is born out of, and encourages, anger and resentment at particular acts committed by the accused. But justice is impartial: it ought to pay no attention to anger caused by particular cases. That the law ought to do anything but deter or rehabilitate is unjust; there's no answer to the frustration of millions of Egyptians in beating up the bad guy.

@Matt in Pittsburgh. You're assuming that because the union job has some overtime work that the union employee will work more hours than a "white" collar job? Absolutely untrue. If you want to keep that white collar job, and especially if you don't want to stay stuck at the entry level responsibility/work forever, you'll need to work 50, 60 or 70 hours per week. And, you won't get payed any overtime. That makes it sound like the union job is even better in comparison.

But here's the thing. Everywhere you turn in the U.S., there will continue to be enormous downward pressure on most wages because of globalization (i.e., the efficient movement of money and information). Just enough white collar work is being outsourced to keep a lid on white collar wages. This will have the effect of exactly what your post implies. More people will opt for blue collar work by design or necessity. This will put downward pressure on blue collar wages (even non-factory jobs like plumbing.). The union salaries are going to get lower and lower over time. A white collar job is no guarantee. But the union job is going to have *much* less upside as the world evolves over the next several decades.

We live in a world of 7 billion people. If you're not willing to work 60 or 70 hours a week, someone else is. Get used to it. The U.S. is not special. There will always be a few high paying jobs. But to get and keep those jobs also requires working 60 or 70 hours a week.

If someone with an MBA or an MD (or any graduate degree, or even a bachelors for that matter) cannot find a job that utilizes their skill and compensates them for their expertise, it is not an issue of laziness...

These jobs are generally a bigger deal for hiring, so companies take a longer time to make their decisions. Allowing these people to collect unemployment while they look for adequate jobs is good for everyone. We live in a (mostly) meritocracy, if people do not believe they will be able to get jobs that compensate them for their training, then we will have real long term decline in education and middle / upper class lifestyle...

The real problem is the people on the fringe of poverty, who actually are better off, or almost better off, collecting unemployment than they are obtaining a low-paying job. These are the people who have an incentive to avoid employment in lieu of collecting unemployment. Do you really think highly trained workers are too lazy to get a job and are content with collecting unemployment, I'd say it's pretty obvious by these people's drive and long-sightedness in pursuing a graduate degree in the first place (or even a bachelors degree) that this is not the case.

Programs that increase poorer peoples earning power, or make unemployment less attractive (In NY benefits are scaled to your previous income) are the way to go, not telling educated people who have done what they were supposed to do to take jobs that are beneath their skill-set.

The people raising animals in industrial settings say they give them antibiotics to increase the rate of their growth and weight gain, not to help them stay healthy.  I suspect that the truth is that the antibiotics do both of these things -- ("healthy" being a very relative term in this context, of course!) but I have not yet heard anyone say they suspect the massive amounts of antibiotics in our meat might be one of the drivers of the astonishing obesity "epidemic."  If antibiotics make animals gain weight quickly, they are doubtless in those same animals when we eat them, and make us do the same.  Why don't we read or hear about this obvious connection?

I would like to thank all the men and women, past, present, and future that have, are, and will serve.  You are helping to protect my first amendment right to free speech.  I doubt many commenters would be willing put on the uniform to defend that right.   It is very easy to people to propose all sorts of cuts to the Defense budget of all sorts of percentages. I agree that downsizing of the military is needed but we have to be smart about it.  There are some weapon systems that could be cut and development on others should be halted.  Cuts to people programs should be avoided.  The federal government needs to be smarter about they way they conduct business.   For example, why can't the Social Security Administration, the Civil Service, and Defense Finance Accounting Service use a common data base for reporting death information, deposit information?  When my mother went to apply for benefits after my dad's passing, she had to fill out three sets of paperwork.  I have to say the SSA was the worst of lot.  Little things like that could save a lot of money.   Again thanks to our women and men in uniform.
